title: Monday, 18th March 2019
bodyHTML:
11:05 am

11:17 am

BE11:18am

In our view, CBK offers an attractive entry opportunity into Germany, i.e. the largest European economy for any bank looking to make inroads in the market and hence M&A speculation has been abundant. However, cross-border M&A in the near to medium term looks unlikely in Europe; and hence we continue to believe a domestic solution possibly involving DBK is the more likely outcome if M&A were to take place. We remain OW CBK, as we would expect a premium to be paid to CBK S/Hs in the scenario of such a potential deal and we see risk/reward attractive at 0.3x P/TBV for a bank with relatively clean balance sheet. We remain Neutral on DBK, as stabilisation of CIB market share is key for the stock but we have little evidence of this based on 4Q results and 1Q performance for industry IB revenues has been challenging YoY (JPMe FICC -13% and Equities -17% YoY) due to weak Equity transaction volumes as well as materially weaker ECM (-45% YoY).

nightingale20201 morning all
11:18 am
BE11:18am

[T]he sensitivity to DBK potentially acquiring CBK has two steps in our base case: 1) a share swap offering a 20% premium pre-dilution to CBK share price, and 2) recapitalisation through negative goodwill (badwill) back to 13% leading to -5% adj. EPS dilution by 2021E. Without using badwill in CET1 and instead doing a €9bn cap raise (even assuming potential asset disposals such as mBank and Comdirect) would not be acceptable to CBK S/H in our view as the dilution would be material at -33% in 2021E and -17% even with full synergies in 2024E. In our view, for DBK, considering the low overall pro-forma RoTE of only 4.6%/6.0% by 2021E/2024E, the rationale to undertake any potential transaction is “liability optimisation” with: i) 55% retail/commercial bank earnings, ii) pro-forma German gov’t stake of c6%, and iii) €25bn of excess retail deposits from CBK leading to L-T funding cost decline. With our assumption of CBK S/Hs likely demanding a premium in any such transaction, we remain OW CBK and Neutral on DBK.

A. M. @VV75: when are the next elections?
FATDAZ @Pharma noted but I didn't draw it yet the story of declining margins increased cost and ROTE near to or below cost of capital for European banks doesn't go away
BE11:18am

DBK-CBK share swap at 20% premium to current CBK share price would be accretive in 2024E with revenue loss at 2.5% of combined revenue base and cost synergies 30% of CBK’s cost base over five years using mainly natural turnover at 2% p.a. on c80k employees in Germany. We estimate combined in-scope costs of €13bn, and cost synergies of €2bn pro-forma, i.e. 15% of in-scope costs. We expect funding spreads to decline by 75bps for DBK with €20-25bn p.a. of funding needs pro-forma, thus proving to be a long-term driver with 6% earnings accretion contribution after five years. We note that the execution risk is high for any such potential transaction with DBK already having lots on its plate currently such as: i) stabilisation of CIB market share, ii) Postbank integration, and iii) delivery on the cost saving plan

BE11:19am

"accretive in 2024E with revenue loss at 2.5% of combined revenue base and cost synergies 30% of CBK’s cost base over five years using mainly natural turnover at 2% p.a. on c80k employees in Germany." ...... Holy god .......

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Post the share swap, we estimate pro-forma YE2018 CET1 ratio of c11% for the combined entity and hence we assume badwill as part of CET1 in our base case. Why? In a scenario of badwill not being counted as CET1, an estimated capital increase of €9bn even assuming mBank and Comdirect asset disposals would not be acceptable to CBK S/Hs in our view due to the material dilution of -33% in 2021E and -17% in 2024E.

JP11:19am

(Ooof.)

red @ FATDAZu can make a case for cost cuts but won't they then just continue to do the saem things wrong. a change of culture is needed.
BE11:20am

And if you want the nil-premium maths, here's RBC.

Pharma Why would any sane bank want to enter the domestic German market? Better to leave them to it.@FATDAZ, true. Rates are silly in the EZ, and no sign of them going up any time soon.
11:20 am
BE11:20am

In our base case (cost savings at 30% of CBK’s costs, revenue loss at 8% of CBK’s revenues, CBK shareholders receive DBK shares at current share prices), the combined group ROTE goes up by 2 pct pts to 7.5% in 2021 and 7% in case of an additional 1% capital buffer, a lot of risk to reach an ROTE still well below the COE. The deal would also do little to change the investment cases. We already give CBK and DBK credit for cost control but are concerned about the revenue outlook. Our proprietary survey of German retail customers confirms this with around 50% of customers potentially moving part of their banking relationship as a result of the merger. This might even be higher among corporate customers. We continue to prefer CBK’s shares over DBK’s shares (UP, Spec. Risk, EUR7.5 PT). Our PT for CBK of EUR8ps (from EUR8.5, please see pg.13 for estimate changes) includes EUR1ps as takeover premium (OP, Spec Risk). Our survey suggests that a merger could lead to market share gains of other players which we believe offer a better value proposition on fundamentals, namely UCG (rated TP), BNP (OP) and ING (SP).

BE11:21am

At a CBK share price of EUR7 we calculate a ROI of 6% in 2019 but rising to 9% in 2021 pre any synergies. Assuming cost savings at 30% of CBK’s costs, a loss of 8% of CBK’s revenues (EUR1.4bn net) and restructuring charges at 1.8x cost savings (EUR3.7bn), we calculate an ROI of 19% in 2021 (CBK share price of EUR7). The NPV of synergies per CBK shares is EUR1 if weighted by market cap (EUR3ps total). In combination with cost savings already in our estimates for both, this takes total cost savings to 17% of combined costs. At a value per CBK share of EUR8.5 (30% premium over 3 months VWAP of EUR6.5), we calculate a 2021 ROI of 12%.

JP11:21am

(@Pharma...yes, pretty much.)

11:21 am
BE11:21am

We calculate the deal will be dilutive to 2021 EPS by 8% (CBK share price of EUR7, DBK EUR8) but 9% accretive factoring in synergies. In case of a 30% premium to 3mths VWAP, the deal would be 2% EPS dilutive. If DBK pays with its shares, the combined pro forma CET1 ratio 1.1.2019 would be 13.4%. However, more capital might be needed to pre fund the restructuring charge (0.5% hit), to cover potential mark
downs and as a buffer for TRIM/B4. An additional 1% capital buffer (EUR5bn) would make the deal at least 8% dilutive to EPS. Our estimates for DBK are materially higher (lower costs) so that based on consensus estimates the deal could be EPS accretive by 9% if CBK’s shares are valued at EUR8.5 and the capital ratio is strengthened by 1%. The German government’s stake might fall from 15% (CBK) to 5% (new group), but in our view Germany might make additional temporary investments in a capital increase of up to 15% in the new entity.

Tom Dalgleish Spinoffs work because they are the opposite of takeovers
FATDAZ @Red I said to my colleagues this morning that the merger will resolve nothing and that we will be having the same conversation about the merged entity in 18 months to two years time

The combined company will be positioned to offer best-in-class enterprise banking, payments, capital markets, and global eCommerce capabilities empowering FIs and merchants worldwide.

BE11:32am

We updated our model to factor 200BPTS in UK-related revenue growth headwinds for CY19 (the UK accounts for 15-20% of sales), incorporating 100BPTS in F/X headwinds (roughly 400BPTS depreciation in GBP/USD rate for Q4/CY18) and another 100 BPTS "hit" in average ticket prices in the UK (reflecting recent UK economic slowdown). We maintain our CEPS estimates reflecting a combination of natural hedges in the model as well as expected mergerrelated synergies. Our new $110 PT, which reflects recent 10-15% multiple contraction for most merchant processing names, assumes a P/E multiple of close to 22X (previous 20X) CY2020 CEPS of $5.00 (rough estimate). Our investment thesis continues to focus on anticipated revenue/cost synergies (integrating Vantiv and legacy WorldPay), improving execution in the UK and continued mix shift in high-growth integrated payments.

undefined

I mean, they seem to have done everything to the Code. But I'd be interested to know what conversations happened in those four days between the stake being bought and the block being lifted.

JP11:43am

The rationale for the deal is that JD Sports management believe that Footasylum is a well-established business with a strong reputation for lifestyle fashion, with a target customer slightly older than JD’s existing proposition. In our view, this looks to be a complementary fascia which can benefit from JD’s sourcing scale, infrastructure and potential international opportunity. Footasylum generated revenues of £195m, adjusted EBITDA of £12.5m and profit before tax of £1.9m for the financial year ended 24th February 2018.

wayneJ Details are at Wikipedia - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pentland_Group
JP11:43am

In our view, this looks a sensible bolt-on acquisition in the UK to the JD Sports group which crystallises the strategic stake that the company acquired back in February in Footasylum. It brings a further fascia to the group and by leveraging JD’s infrastructure and sourcing capabilities will be able to drive out operating synergies, which can potentially be reinvested in the offer. We reiterate our BUY rating.

red or JD believes there will be a growing "off-grid' economy

11:44 am

Thumbs up

BE11:45am

■ If – under JD Sports management - Footasylum were to achieve a
similar EBITDA margin to JD Sports (~10% in 2020) by 2021 that would
add roughly £29m to group EBITDA, a ~5% contribution. JD Sports have
got a strong M&A execution track record (have done acquisitions in the size of £0-£400m considerations before) so the current plan to integrate a small sized business in their home market should not represent material
challenges in our view.
■ A number of synergies can be had as: Footasylum is similar to JD Sport’s
Scott’s Fashion business (~20 stores CS). Centralization of the two
businesses could lead to central cost cuts and benefits from new
opportunities and better buying volumes available to the combined group
compared to what they could achieve on a standalone basis before. Several former JD employees work already in the Footasylum management team
potentially allowing for faster and more effective rationalization between the two businesses.

BE11:45am

We view JD Sports as one of the best positioned sporting goods
distributors globally to benefit from the premium brands’ DTC efforts.
With the shares trading on 13x 2020 earnings for 14% average EPS
growth in 3Y we view the shares as attractive and rate the shares
Outperform.

Yep, it's a feature which pushes the nosecone down to stop the plane stalling.

red @wayneJtrainers a "business expense" for many of the patrons
JP11:51am

It had been investigating the previous crash the plane had been involved in, and had talked to "current and former engineers directly involved with the evaluations or familiar with the document shared details of Boeing’s “System Safety Analysis” of MCAS,"

wayneJ @red - :-)
11:51 am
BE11:51am

.... ok.

JP11:52am

Turns out the safety analysis, which was carried out by Boeing's own engineers, as the FAA is under-resourced, said:

JP11:52am

Understated the power of the new flight control system, which was designed to swivel the horizontal tail to push the nose of the plane down to avert a stall. When the planes later entered service, MCAS was capable of moving the tail more than four times farther than was stated in the initial safety analysis document.
Failed to account for how the system could reset itself each time a pilot responded, thereby missing the potential impact of the system repeatedly pushing the airplane’s nose downward.
Assessed a failure of the system as one level below “catastrophic.” But even that “hazardous” danger level should have precluded activation of the system based on input from a single sensor — and yet that’s how it was designed.

(@BornCynic -- great minds etc.)

BE11:58am

We had been cautious on Hunting given the downside risk to earnings in their US Titan business, but with the recent round of capex comments we believe these risks are now well understood and priced in. Hunting's lesser known international business, which accounts for 30% of revenues but generated an operating loss over the past 4-5 years, is approaching an inflection point and should start to turn positive from 2019. Momentum in the US (non-Titan) business also showed good growth, +30% sequentially into 2H18 and we expect this to continue into 2019. We expect the analyst event mid-May to provide more colour on the growth profile. The shares have de-rated significantly with consensus 1-year forward EV/EBITDA falling from 10x, to the current level of around 6x. With this note we upgrade our 2019 operating profit forecast by 25% (Titan better than expected, Other US and International improving), and upgrade our rating to Buy.

JP12:07pm

The Annual Commercial Space Compendium compiled by the US Federal Aviation
Administration (FAA) identifies a space economy worth just under $400bn. Within
that total, about 28% is for commercial TV, which has not grown substantially in
recent years, and likely has limited scope for growth given the rise of cord-cutting.
Other than that exception, we expect the rest of the space economy to show a 3-
10% CAGR over the next 10 to 15 years, and see the fastest growth opportunity
in the nascent – but potentially fertile – area of commercial space services, of
which space tourism is one segment. But there are other segments, ranging from
the here-and-now (like GPS services and geolocation to the earth imaging) to
longer term business models that are predicated on space based energy
production and resource extraction.
